overview: From 2025-11-07 to 2025-11-08, ethereum-optimism/optimism had 8 new PRs (4 merged), 7 new issues, and 24 active contributors.

topIssues.title: [op-acceptance-tests] Flaky test: TestL2CLAheadOfSupervisor
topIssues.author: scharissis
topIssues.body:
## Description
TestL2CLAheadOfSupervisor has been flaky for quite some time. Lets investigate and fix it.

## (Partial) Flake History
* [22Sep25](https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/ethereum-optimism/optimism/101380/workflows/8d5d9185-1c90-4316-bd80-21a30f2407f6/jobs/3885167/tests)

topIssues.title: Kona + Cannon: standard prestates integration
topIssues.author: pauldowman
topIssues.body:
Integrate Cannon + Kona into our tooling for managing absolute prestates.

- Add support for Cannon + Kona prestates to standard-prestates.toml
  - Use a new field e.g. `program = kona`? Or use `type = cannon-64-kona` or `type = interop-kona`?
  - Or use a separate file for kona prestates? This is easier for tooling but maybe worse for usability?
- Ensure `make reproducible-prestate` supports this (it consumes standard-prestates.toml)

topIssues.title: kurtosis-devnet: hide current output under verbose
topIssues.author: serpixel
topIssues.body: Currently we drop a lot of verbose output that may not really be needed. We have multiple ways to organize this output in the terminal, either by hiding the output under different levels of verbosity or by implementing a LESS output.

topIssues.title: kurtosis-devnet: implement selective devnet containers to speed up startup
topIssues.author: serpixel
topIssues.body:
Make kurtosis services sptional to improve deployment speed as currently deployments are slow due to deploying unnecessary components for certain use cases 
Making components optional would offer more flexibility in creating minimized configuration

topPRs.title: all: Remove cannon-kona dgv2 feature flags
topPRs.author: Inphi
topPRs.body:
To illustrate the change to make cannon-kona and disputegame-v2 the default behavior.

### Unresolved Issues

- Should we maintain deploy scripts for V1 dispute games? These scripts may yet be useful for chains that haven't upgraded. While they will always be available in older op-deployer releases, it's quite convenient for the latest op-deployer to support them.

topPRs.title: op-supernode: Enable P2P for Virtual Nodes
topPRs.author: axelKingsley
topPRs.body:
# What

Enables P2P for Virtual Nodes by taking a top level `op-supervisor` flag `--disable-p2p` and using it to decide how to load the Virtual CLI Contexts for the Nodes.

## What?

In Supernode's `Main`, I take the top level `urface CLI Context` which contains all the runtime flags, and I wrap it with a virtual accessor which can reroute queries. For example, when a Virtual Node asks for some flag value `--x`, we proxy that check to `--chainID.x`. This allows for all Virtual Nodes to share one set of flags including global values, while also allowing per-chain settings.

When `op-supervisor` starts with `--disable-p2p=true`, all P2P configurations are set to zero-values or disabled for all chains.

When `op-supervisor` starts with `--disable-p2p=false`, all P2P configurations are set to use namespaced Data Directories, and use `0` for all port values for dynamic assignment.

## Why?

For a `op-supernode` to sync, it can *either* do a Full Sync, meaning it derives manually from genesis, or it using some Execution Syncing mechanism to push the engine to the tip-state.

Currently, the only way to get a signal to sync towards is over the CL P2P network.

*Personally* I am not a huge fan of `op-supernode` supporting P2P, but given the vital role it serves in first time startup, I've decided to give it some basic enablement.

In the future, if we want a more sophisticated P2P, I recommend we build a shared resource which can deduplicate the number of listening ports. That task is more involved than I'd like to take on to enable P2P for the moment.

## Tests
Locally tested to confirm on/off both set P2P correctly.

Also running this in our actual infrastructure, which confirms this change is what's required to enable the `op-supernode` to correctly sync and start up.

I've heard that writing P2P tests that are meaningful and not flaky is very difficult so I've avoided it for this endeavor, but would accept pushback if there's a specific type of testing this PR deserves.

# Also

Rewrote the README.md at the same time since this change caused me to open it up and realize it's a little stale.

topPRs.title: ci: Prepare for kona prestate verification
topPRs.author: Inphi
topPRs.body:
Add support for cannon-kona prestate build in the monorepo. Depends on updates to the standard prestates in the superchain-registry - https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry/pull/1144

### Testing
```bash
cd op-program
scripts/build-prestates.sh
go run ./prestates/verify/verify.go \
  --input temp/states/versions.json  \
  --expected ../../superchain-registry/validation/standard/standard-prestates.toml # get this from the above pr
```

fixes https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/issues/17283

completedItems.title: refactor(scripts): remove GenerateOPCMMigrateCalldata script
completedItems.body:
## Changes
- Remove `packages/contracts-bedrock/scripts/deploy/GenerateOPCMMigrateCalldata.sol`

## Why
This script is being removed as part of the cleanup work ahead of OPCMv2. The script generated calldata for `OPCM.migrate` function

completedItems.title: op-devstack: remove fetching for cluster depset
batch_decoder: Fix & allow config loading via L2 chain ID
completedItems.body:
**Description**

Fixes the batch decoder to have a full rollup config for `reassemble` and allow loading of it via the `l2-chain-id` flag. Also improves the `fetch` command to also allow only setting the L2 chain id.

**Tests**

Tes
